text:
(1)
Abingdon Square, looking north from Hudson Street at Bank Street, where Eighth Avenue branches off to the right, showing a row of old houses on the 12th Street side of the square, shortly to be demolished. Jeffersonian Club (Democratic, 3rd A.D. South) is in the center of this block.

April 3, 1929.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

(2)
The same, showing houses on 12th Street side demolished, all but the corner one at 8th Street, which was spared.

To the right is a bandstand and comfort station, and behind it part of Abingdon Hotel and old houses.

May 27, 1930.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

(3)
The same, showing new apartment building No. 299 West 12th Street under construction. On right, last glimpse of Abingdon Hotel, about to be torn down.

February 6, 1931.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

Bank Street, north side, west from and including Hudson Street, at the southern end of Abingdon Square. Part of the Abingdon Square bandstand and comfort station is shown at the extreme right. The General Electric Supply Corporation Building is 585-591 Hudson Street, filling the block from Bank to Bethune Streets.

May 30, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Abingdon Square, looking north from Hudson Street at Bank Street, where Eighth Avenue branches off to the right.

New apartment buildings, 299 West 12th Street on north side of square, and building at S.E. corner of Eighth Avenue and 12th Street. Behind bandstand is vacant lot where Abingdon Hotel has been demolished.

March 15, 1932.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

(2)
The same view as No. 1 but four months later, showing in background the skeleton of Port Authority Building between Eighth and Ninth Avenues just north of 14th Street.

July 17, 1932.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

(3)
The same view at a later date.

October 2, 1938.

P. L. Sperr.

October 2, 1938.

P. L. Sperr.

Abingdon Square, looking north on Eighth Avenue (left) and east on Bank Street (right) from S.W. corner of Bank and Hudson Streets, showing the bandstand and comfort station, used for Sunday afternoon concerts by Jeffersonian (Democratic) Club. Behind bandstand is a lot left vacant by demolition of Abingdon Hotel and adjoining old houses; two squatters will be camping there during 1934.

Loew's Sheridan Theatre cuts off Bank Street at the farther end.

March 12, 1933.

P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

Hudson Street, west side, from Bank (left of No. 1), to W. 12th (right of No. 2) Streets, showing buildings thereupon as viewed across a clearance on the east side of Abingdon Square between Bank Street and Eighth Avenue.

"The thoroughfare in the center separating these blocks is Bethune Street and thru which appears a glimpse of the Ninth Avenue "El" running on Greenwich Street. The G. E. Supply Corp. building occupies the Bank-Bethune Street frontage, while to the north are dwellings between Bethune and W. 12th Streets.

Eighth Avenue begins at this point and runs at the right over the exposed sub-basement and to the front of the exposed building rears.

The six story building with the white trim, located at the S. W. corner of Hudson and W. 12th Streets is the Laura Spellman Hall of the Young Women's Christian Association. The trees partially hiding same are in the triangular park named for the daughter of Sir Peter Warren. This separates Eighth Avenue from Hudson Street.

Upon the foreground site formerly stood No's. 1, 3, 5, and 7-9 Abingdon Square (q.v.); the last being the Abingdon Hotel. These were demolished in May 1931.

Gift of Committee on Housing Charity Organization Society

1935 Views: 1-3
